summary: A survey of the premodern world, focusing on geographic organization, trade routes, and the prevalence of centralized dynastic rule (monarchy) and social hierarchy [3, 4]. It introduces the concept of the divine right of kings [4, 5].

Examines the development of revolutionary political ideals rooted in the Enlightenment and Greco-Roman philosophy, emphasizing concepts like the rule of law, reason, and individual rights [6-8]. It compares major revolutions (English, American, French, Haitian) [9]. It also covers the causes and consequences of the Industrial Revolution, including technological advances, shifts in work patterns, and resulting social inequality and socialist ideologies [10-13].

Focuses on the rise of industrial economies and their link to imperial expansion, covering economic and ideological motives (such as ‘civilizing mission’ and racial hierarchy) [14, 15]. It includes case studies in regions like China, India, and Latin America, noting how non-industrial countries responded to pressure or maintained independence [14, 16-18].

unit_title: Global Conflict and Totalitarianism (WWI, WWII, Cold War)
summary: Analyzes the causes and course of World War I, including the concept of 'total war' and postwar disillusionment [19-21]. It examines the rise of totalitarian governments (Fascism, Nazism, Communism) as alternatives to capitalism during the Great Depression [22]. It covers World War II, the Holocaust, and the origins and initial strategies of the Cold War, including containment and proxy wars [23-26].

Explores nation-building struggles in the post–Cold War world and how nations organized themselves politically and economically [27]. Topics include subsequent genocides (Cambodia, Rwanda) [28] and the increasing integration of countries through technological, economic, and communications revolutions (globalization) [29, 30].
